On the subject of single-pass activation, =
there is a potential gotcha...

As long as the network is not recurrent, yo=
u're fine.  As soon as it
becomes recurrent, you have to make a decision ab=
out how to order the
firing, because there is no 'correct' way.  Here's the=
 gotcha:  When
you add topology to an existing network, it may cause you to=
 make a
different choice of what order to activate it.  Topology and weight=
s
that may have been tuned to a particular firing order may suddenly get
fi=
red in a different order, which may cause it to take a huge hit in
fitness.=
  For a discriminator network, that shouldn't ever be a
problem.  For a con=
troller, it may very well present a problem to the
evolution of the network=
.

The solution, of course, is to have a deterministic approach to
determin=
ing firing order that will NOT have any possibility of the
addition of new =
topology changing the firing order of any of the old
topology that is not c=
onnected to that new topology.  When you have a
loop, and you need to deter=
mine which path to activate first, you have
some choices to make:

1. You c=
an't choose randomly, because that's not deterministic
2. You could choose =
to activate the longest path first, but then you
run the risk of new topolo=
gy changing the firing order
3. Or the best option:  Choose based on AGE of=
 the topology.  

With option 3, you get a deterministic method of determin=
ing firing
order that will not be suceptable to the problems that the evolu=
tion
of new topology might cause.

However, that said, it is entirely possi=
ble that having such a firing
pattern might make a controller network harde=
r to evolve, as you might
potentially lose the ability to have a 'time dela=
y' circuit.

If I were you, I would retain the ability to fire the networks=
 using
either method.  Choose the firing-order optimizer for classifier
net=
works, to speed up your evolution, and use the real-time firing
method for =
controllers that need to have time-based processing.
